docs.lead_paragraph: Two brothers’ journey to make a kidney transplant happen has taken them to the core of the national impasse between health care and immigration policies.

headline.seo: Illegal Immigrant’s Transplant, Cheaper Over Life, Isn’t Covered
headline.main: For Illegal Immigrant, Line Is Drawn at Transplant
headline.print_headline: For Illegal Resident, Line Is Drawn at Transplant

docs.abstract: Story of two brothers, one an illegal immigrant in his early 30s who desperately requires a liver transplant, goes to the heart of a national impasse between health care and immigration policies; government is willing to pay $75,000 per year for a lifetime of dialysis, but not the $100,000 for a transplant that would make treatment unnecessary; for nearly two years, brothers and their supporters have been hunting for a way to make the transplant possible.
docs.snippet: Two brothers’ journey to make a kidney transplant happen has taken them to the core of the national impasse between health care and immigration policies.

docs.lead_paragraph: Regulators want banks to finance their operations with more capital and less borrowed money, but that means less profits and lower bonuses.

headline.seo: A Fight to Make Banks More Prudent
headline.main: A Fight to Make Banks More Prudent
headline.print_headline: A Fight to Make Banks More Prudent

docs.abstract: Federal Reserve publishes draft regulations that draw heavily on the agreements reached in Basel, which would require banks to finance their operations with more capital and less borrowed money, but banks oppose regulations that mean less profits and lower bonuses; economists fear long phase-in period will allow banking industry to water down the rules, negating the benefits of stricter regulations.
docs.snippet: Regulators want banks to finance their operations with more capital and less borrowed money, but that means less profits and lower bonuses.

docs.lead_paragraph: A surprise announcement Friday to give states broad leeway to pick benefits under the federal health care law offered another example of a gradualist style regarding the policy.

headline.seo: Obama’s Piecemeal Approach to Health Law in States
headline.main: A Piecemeal Approach to Health Law in States
headline.print_headline: A Piecemeal Approach To Health Law in States

docs.abstract: News analysis; Obama administration's surprise announcement that it plans to give states broad leeway to pick benefits under the federal health care law offers yet another example of a gradualist approach to carrying out its signal domestic policy achievement.
docs.snippet: A surprise announcement Friday to give states broad leeway to pick benefits under the federal health care law offered another example of a gradualist style regarding the policy.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

byline.original: By GARDINER HARRIS, REED ABELSON and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration's surprise announcement Friday that it planned to give states broad leeway to pick the benefits offered under the federal health care law offers yet another example of a gradualist approach to carrying out its signal domestic policy achievement. Facing vociferous Republican opposition, a looming Supreme Court decision on the constitutionality of the law and the practical challenges of overhauling the vast health insurance market for small businesses and individuals, federal officials are choosing to avoid some crucial choices until well after the 2012 elections. While critics accuse the administration of political expediency, the officials insist the decisions have been based on sound policy judgments.

headline.main: A Piecemeal Approach To Health Law in States

headline.main: Yale and Columbia Reimburse Gay Employees for Extra Taxes

docs.abstract: Columbia and Yale will soon begin to reimburse its gay employees for the extra costs that they owe on the value of their partners' health insurance.
docs.snippet: Columbia and Yale will soon begin to reimburse its gay employees for the extra costs that they owe on the value of their partners' health insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: This is really awful. Politifact, which is supposed to police false claims in politics, has announced its Lie of the Year -- and it's a statement that happens to be true, the claim that Republicans have voted to end Medicare.
